title: Stephen Allen Benson
text:
Stephen Allen Benson (May 21, 1816 – January 24, 1865) was a <a href="Liberia">Liberia</a>n politician who served as the <a href="President%20of%20Liberia%23List%20of%20Presidents%20of%20Liberia">2nd</a> <a href="President%20of%20Liberia">President of Liberia</a> from 1856 to 1864. Prior to that, he served as the <a href="Vice%20President%20of%20Liberia%23List%20of%20Vice%20Presidents%20of%20Liberia">3rd</a> <a href="Vice%20President%20of%20Liberia">Vice President of Liberia</a> from 1854 to 1856 under President <a href="Joseph%20Jenkins%20Roberts">Joseph Jenkins Roberts</a>. Born in the United States, Benson was the first president to have lived in <a href="Liberia">Liberia</a> since childhood, having arrived with his family in 1822.
Early life.
Benson was born in <a href="Cambridge%2C%20Maryland">Cambridge, Maryland</a>, United States, to freeborn African-American parents. In 1822, his family emigrated to the newly established country of Liberia, sailing aboard the "Brig Strong".
For four years, he was a military shopkeeper. He was also a private secretary to <a href="Thomas%20Buchanan%20%28Governor%20of%20Liberia%29">Thomas Buchanan</a>, the last of Liberia's white governors. Benson later became a successful businessman. Benson joined the <a href="militia">militia</a> in 1835, and in 1842 became a delegate to the Colonial Council. After <a href="History%20of%20Liberia">Liberia's independence</a> in 1847 he became a judge. He was also a <a href="Methodist">Methodist</a> preacher. Benson was the <a href="Secretary%20of%20the%20Treasury%20of%20Liberia">Secretary of the Treasury</a> before becoming the president. 
Presidency (1856–64).
In 1853 Benson became the vice president to <a href="Joseph%20Jenkins%20Roberts">Joseph Jenkins Roberts</a>, serving in that capacity until winning the presidency in 1856.
Foreign relations.
Benson obtained <a href="diplomatic%20recognition">diplomatic recognition</a> for Liberia from Belgium in 1858, Denmark in 1860, the United States and Italy in 1862, Norway and Sweden in 1863, and Haiti in 1864.
Expansion.
In 1857, Benson organized the <a href="annexation">annexation</a> of the <a href="Republic%20of%20Maryland">Republic of Maryland</a>. By 1860, through treaties and purchases with local African leaders, Liberia had extended its boundaries to include a 600-mile (1000km) coastline.
Retirement.
After the end of his presidency Benson retired to his coffee <a href="plantation">plantation</a> in <a href="Grand%20Bassa%20County">Grand Bassa County</a> where he died in 1865.
Legacy.
Benson is commemorated in the scientific name of a species of lizard, "<a href="Trachylepis%20bensonii">Trachylepis bensonii</a>", which is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to Liberia.
